items.title: Russia killed opposition leader Alexei Navalny using dart frog toxin, UK says

items.content: There is no innocent explanation for the toxin being found in samples taken from Navalny's body, Foreign Office says.

items.title: Russia fatally 'poisoned' Putin critic Navalny with rare toxin, UK says
items.standfirst: Five European countries accused Russia of "poisoning" opposition leader Alexei Navalny using a rare toxin found in South American dart frogs, according to a joint statement issued Saturday. A leading critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony in February 2024. France24 correspondent Benedicte Paviot reports the latest from London.
items.content: Five European countries accused Russia of "poisoning" opposition leader Alexei Navalny using a rare toxin found in South American dart frogs, according to a joint statement issued Saturday. A leading critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony in February 2024. France24 correspondent Benedicte Paviot reports the latest from London.

items.title: European states accuse Russia of Navanlny poisoning
items.standfirst: Five European countries, including Britain, France and Germany, accused Russia on Saturday of having poisoned jailed opposition figure Alexei Navalny with a rare and lethal toxin in 2024, speaking on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, as the United Kingdom, Sweden, France, Germany and Netherlands said in a joint statement that analyses of samples from Navalny’s body left them confident he had been poisoned, following the death of the outspoken critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin in an Arctic prison in February 2024 while he was serving a 19-year sentence. France24 correspondent Nick Holdsworth reports from Munich.
items.content: Five European countries, including Britain, France and Germany, accused Russia on Saturday of having poisoned jailed opposition figure Alexei Navalny with a rare and lethal toxin in 2024, speaking on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, as the United Kingdom, Sweden, France, Germany and Netherlands said in a joint statement that analyses of samples from Navalny’s body left them confident he had been poisoned, following the death of the outspoken critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin in an Arctic prison in February 2024 while he was serving a 19-year sentence. France24 correspondent Nick Holdsworth reports from Munich.

items.title: Why do European governments say Navalny was poisoned? #world
items.standfirst: New analysis points to a rare, lethal toxin European foreign ministries in several countries say tests on samples from the late Russian opposition figure revealed traces of a rare and deadly toxin derived from poison dart frogs. The chemical identified, epibatidine, is not a commonplace…
items.content: New analysis points to a rare, lethal toxin European foreign ministries in several countries say tests on samples from the late Russian opposition figure revealed traces of a rare and deadly toxin derived from poison dart frogs. items.title: Russia killed Alexei Navalny with frog toxin, UK and four European allies say
items.standfirst: Intelligence agencies say deadly toxin in skin of Ecuador dart frogs found in Navalny’s body and highly likely resulted in his deathMunich Security Conference – live updatesAlexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, was killed by dart frog poison administered by the Russian state two years ago, a multi-intelligence agency inquiry has found, according to a statement released by five countries, the UK, France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands.The US was not one of the intelligence agencies making the claim. Continue reading...
items.content: Intelligence agencies say deadly toxin in skin of Ecuador dart frogs found in Navalny’s body and highly likely resulted in his deathMunich Security Conference – live updatesAlexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, was killed by dart frog poison administered by the Russian state two years ago, a multi-intelligence agency inquiry has found, according to a statement released by five countries, the UK, France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands.The US was not one of the intelligence agencies making the claim. Continue reading...

items.title: 5 European nations say Alexei Navalny was poisoned and blame the Kremlin

items.content: In a joint statement, the foreign ministries of the U.K., France, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands say Navalny was poisoned by Russia with a lethal toxin derived from the skin of poison dart frogs.(Image credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko)

items.title: Rubio says US and Europe 'belong together' despite tensions
items.standfirst: The US secretary of state reassures European leaders that the Trump administration backs the transatlantic alliance.
items.content: The US secretary of state reassures European leaders that the Trump administration backs the transatlantic alliance.

items.title: Rubio says US and Europe "belong together"
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio sought to assuage European leaders' worries about fraying ties with Washington as he addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, telling the annual gathering that Europe and the US "belong together" and that Washington wants to "revitalise" the transatlantic alliance. France24 journalist Andrew Hilliar explains.
items.content: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio sought to assuage European leaders' worries about fraying ties with Washington as he addressed the Munich Security Conference on Saturday, telling the annual gathering that Europe and the US "belong together" and that Washington wants to "revitalise" the transatlantic alliance. France24 journalist Andrew Hilliar explains.

items.title: Marco Rubio has warmer words for Europe weeks after Trump's harsh Davos comments
items.standfirst: Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday in an apparent effort to paper over cracks in the relationship between the U.S. and Europe, though foreign diplomats were less convinced that real change would follow
items.content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday in an apparent effort to paper over cracks in the relationship between the U.S. and Europe, though foreign diplomats were less convinced that real change would follow

items.title: Munich Security talks: Rubio says US wants to "revitalise" transatlantic alliance
items.standfirst: Marco Rubio’s address at the Munich Security Conference marked a more conciliatory stance for the U.S., following Vice President JD Vance’s harsh critique of Europe last year for ignoring an internal “threat,” shirking its defense responsibilities, and allowing left-wing influence in cultural matters. Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. Senior Fellow at Scowcroft Center for Strategy and Security, Elisabeth Brown, tells us more.
items.content: Marco Rubio’s address at the Munich Security Conference marked a more conciliatory stance for the U.S., following Vice President JD Vance’s harsh critique of Europe last year for ignoring an internal “threat,” shirking its defense responsibilities, and allowing left-wing influence in cultural matters. Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. Senior Fellow at Scowcroft Center for Strategy and Security, Elisabeth Brown, tells us more.

Although Rubio still encouraged European allies to consider policies akin to Donald Trump’s America, his speech clearly aimed to ease tensions and mend transatlantic relations. clusters.title: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
clusters.neutral_headline: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Reuters Top News, Sky News World and others

items.title: Second US carrier heads to Middle East
items.standfirst: US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner are set to hold talks with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, as Donald Trump told reporters on Friday that regime change would be the best possible outcome for the country, remarks that come as a second US aircraft carrier is redeployed toward the Middle East from the Caribbean, a journey expected to take at least a week. Peter O'Brien reports.
items.content: US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner are set to hold talks with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, as Donald Trump told reporters on Friday that regime change would be the best possible outcome for the country, remarks that come as a second US aircraft carrier is redeployed toward the Middle East from the Caribbean, a journey expected to take at least a week. Peter O'Brien reports.

items.content: A partial government shutdown began on midnight Saturday after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on Department of Homeland Security funding.

items.title: Limited government shutdown likely to linger for at least 10 days as Congress takes break
items.standfirst: 13% of federal civilian workforce is affected, although DHS – which spurred budget standoff – remains fundedA limited US government shutdown came into effect on Saturday – the third of Donald Trump’s second term – after negotiations between the White House and Democrats in Congress failed to agree on new restrictions for federal immigration agents.The shutdown affects about 13% of the federal civilian workforce and is confined to agencies under the umbrella of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), including the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), which screens airline passengers. Continue reading...
items.content: 13% of federal civilian workforce is affected, although DHS – which spurred budget standoff – remains fundedA limited US government shutdown came into effect on Saturday – the third of Donald Trump’s second term – after negotiations between the White House and Democrats in Congress failed to agree on new restrictions for federal immigration agents.The shutdown affects about 13% of the federal civilian workforce and is confined to agencies under the umbrella of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), including the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), which screens airline passengers. items.title: Budget standoff over immigration shuts down US Department of Homeland Security
items.standfirst: A prolonged impasse between US lawmakers over immigration enforcement ensnared the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a partial government shutdown on Saturday, with Democrats in Congress vowing to withhold funding until major changes are enacted in the wake of two fatal shootings by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis.
items.content: A prolonged impasse between US lawmakers over immigration enforcement ensnared the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a partial government shutdown on Saturday, with Democrats in Congress vowing to withhold funding until major changes are enacted in the wake of two fatal shootings by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis.

items.title: US strikes dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria in retaliation for deadly ambush

items.title: Why did the EPA repeal the endangerment finding? #science
items.standfirst: What the change does and why it matters The agency's decision removes a foundational scientific conclusion that greenhouse gases pose a danger to human health and welfare. That 2009 finding has been the legal basis for a wide range of federal rules controlling emissions from vehicles, power plants…
items.content: What the change does and why it matters The agency's decision removes a foundational scientific conclusion that greenhouse gases pose a danger to human health and welfare. That 2009 finding has been the legal basis for a wide range of federal rules controlling emissions from vehicles, power plants…

items.title: What does revoking the EPA 'endangerment finding' mean? #science

That finding served as the legal and scientific basis for a wide range of federal…
